Quoth Curt Sampson:
  [...]
> I wouldn't, because it was test-driven development that drove me to the
> above solution in the first place. I thought, "Darn, to test this I've
> got to make another mock object here, and pass it a database connection.
> Why not just pass in the connection directly, and save myself the effort?"

For reference, I quote the original code snippet again:

> Object doMyThing(Connection con, String something)
> {
>     // do stuff on the connection and return the object.
> }
>
> public Object doMyThing(ConnectionFactory factory, String something)
> {
>     Connection con = factory.getConnection();
>     return doMyThing(con, something);
>     con.close();
> }

I see your point that having to mock both ConnectionFactory and
Connection is annoying, and the addition of the first method
solves this problem.

I do wonder, however, why the second method (i.e., the original
one before the testability question came up) requires a
ConnectionFactory in the first place.  If the code's use of the
factory is as simple as the above example suggests, why not write
a Connection proxy which grabs a real connection from the pool as
needed?  In other words, what use is the Factory pattern here, and
why does the caller need to know about it?

(Would I know the answers to these questions if I knew what
Websphere is?)
